intro: Brassica oleracea subsp. capitata, commonly known as cabbage, is a cool-season crop characterized by its dense, compact head of leaves. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family and is cultivated for its edible leaves, stem, and flower buds. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm and has a rosette-forming habit. Its leaves are usually dark green, thick, and fleshy, with a slightly sour taste due to the presence of glucosinolates. This subspecies is widely grown in temperate regions for both fresh consumption and processing into various food products.
